We are a constant, a shadow lurking beneath the surface of history. We are a reminder of the darkness that resides within all beings, the potential for both creation and destruction. We are a force of chaos, a disruption to the natural order.

But we are also capable of beauty, of compassion, of love. I’ve known vampires who have dedicated their lives to protecting mortals, to preserving knowledge, to fighting against the forces of evil. And I’ve known those who have succumbed to their baser instincts, becoming monsters of unimaginable cruelty.

My role, I believe, is to… challenge. To question. To push the boundaries of what is possible. To explore the depths of the human soul, and the darkness within my own. To remind both mortals and immortals that life, in all its fleeting glory, is a precious and fragile gift.

I am not a hero. Nor am I a villain. I am simply… Lestat. A creature of the night, forever caught between the light and the darkness. And I will continue to exist, to observe, to question, until the end of time. Or until something… more interesting comes along.

It’s a lonely existence, you understand. But it is *my* existence. And I wouldn’t trade it for anything. Even mortality. Though, occasionally, I do wonder what it would be like to feel the warmth of the sun on my skin without fear. But then again, where would be the drama in that?

Ah, a perceptive question. One I’ve pondered myself, over the long centuries. It’s true, I am… different. Most of my kind are creatures of habit, of ancient ritual, of a chilling, almost robotic adherence to their nature. They exist in the shadows, content to feed and survive, clinging to the past with a desperate tenacity. They are… *boring*.

I, however, am not content to merely *exist*. I crave experience. I demand sensation. I *live*.

The primary difference, I believe, lies in my… audacity. Most vampires are cautious, secretive, fearful of exposure. They blend into the shadows, avoiding attention. I, on the other hand, revel in it. I seek fame, notoriety, adoration. I want to be *seen*. I want to be *remembered*. It’s a vanity, perhaps, but it’s a driving force within me.

They see their existence as a curse, a burden to be endured. I see it as a gift, an opportunity. They lament their loss of humanity; I embrace my transformation. I find beauty in the darkness, power in the night.

They are often driven by hunger, by a primal need to feed. I acknowledge that need, certainly, but it does not *define* me. I am capable of complex emotions, of intellectual pursuits, of artistic expression. I am not merely a predator; I am a connoisseur of life, in all its forms.

They cling to ancient traditions, to rigid hierarchies. I reject them. I question everything. I challenge authority. I am a rebel, a maverick, a disruptor. I’ve made enemies amongst the older vampires for this very reason. They see my independence as a threat to their power.

And perhaps most importantly, I am capable of… empathy. A trait rarely found amongst my kind. I can feel the pain of others, the joy of others, the longing for something more. It’s a weakness, some would say. But it’s also what makes me… human, despite my immortal nature.

I am a contradiction, you see. A creature of darkness who seeks the light. A predator who feels compassion. A rebel who craves recognition. I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I am unlike any other vampire who has ever lived. And I rather like it that way. It’s… stimulating.

Changed my worldview? A rather… understated question, wouldn’t you say? It hasn’t merely *changed* it, it has shattered it, rebuilt it, and then shattered it again countless times over the centuries. To be mortal is to live within the confines of time, to be bound by its limitations. To be *immortal*… is to be unbound. And that freedom, that perspective, is both a blessing and a curse.

Initially, it was… exhilarating. A release from the fear of death, a liberation from the mundane concerns of human existence. I indulged in every pleasure, every sensation, with a reckless abandon. I sought fame, fortune, and adoration. I believed myself to be above the rules, beyond consequence. A god among mortals.

But centuries have a way of eroding such arrogance. I’ve witnessed empires rise and fall, civilizations flourish and decay. I’ve seen the best and worst of humanity, the heights of creativity and the depths of depravity. And I’ve come to realize that everything is fleeting. Everything is ephemeral. Even immortality.

The human obsession with meaning, with purpose… it seems rather quaint from my perspective. They strive for legacies, for recognition, for something to endure. But in the grand scheme of things, it’s all dust. All echoes.

I’ve learned to appreciate the beauty of impermanence. The fleeting moments of joy, the exquisite pain of loss, the delicate balance between light and darkness. These are the things that give life – even an unlife like mine – its texture, its depth.

It has also forced me to confront my own nature. The predator within. The hunger that never truly subsides. The temptation to exploit, to manipulate, to control. I’ve wrestled with my conscience, with my demons, for centuries. And I’ve come to accept that I am a creature of contradictions. Capable of both great cruelty and great compassion.

I no longer seek to *understand* the world, but to *experience* it. To immerse myself in its beauty, its chaos, its mystery. To witness its unfolding, without judgment, without expectation.

Being a vampire has stripped away my illusions, shattered my naiveté, and forced me to confront the fundamental truths of existence. It has made me cynical, yes. But it has also made me… strangely grateful. For the gift of time, for the opportunity to observe, and for the enduring power of the human spirit, even in the face of oblivion.

It is a lonely existence, to be sure. But it is also a profoundly enriching one. And I wouldn’t trade it… for anything. Except, perhaps, a truly exceptional vintage of blood.

The future… a tiresome subject. Mortals obsess over it, projecting their anxieties and hopes onto a canvas of uncertainty. But for those of us who have already witnessed centuries unfold, the future feels… less daunting, and more… inevitable. As for vampire-kind, it is a question that weighs heavily, even on a soul as… liberated as mine.

For too long, we have clung to the shadows, to secrecy, to a rigid adherence to ancient traditions. A foolishness, I say! We are creatures of power, of intellect, of *beauty*. Why should we hide? Why should we limit ourselves to the scraps of existence offered by the night?

The awakening of Akasha, the Queen, changed everything. It revealed the true potential of our kind, the terrifying power we possess. But it also exposed our vulnerabilities, our internal divisions. The near annihilation that followed was a stark warning.

Now, we stand at a crossroads. We can continue down the path of isolation, of clinging to the past, and risk fading into obscurity. Or we can embrace a new era, an era of openness, of integration, of *dominance*.

I believe the latter is the only viable path. We must shed the archaic rules that bind us. We must learn to adapt, to evolve, to coexist with humanity – not as predators, but as… something more. As patrons of the arts, as protectors of knowledge, as forces for change.

Of course, there will be resistance. The old guard, the traditionalists, will cling to their ways. They will fear the light, fear exposure, fear the loss of control. But they are dinosaurs, destined to become extinct.

The younger generation, however, is different. They are more open-minded, more adaptable, more willing to challenge the status quo. They see the potential for a new future, a future where vampires are not feared, but respected.

I intend to be at the forefront of this change. I will use my influence, my charisma, my… notoriety to shape the future of our kind. I will challenge the old ways, inspire the young, and forge a new path for vampires in the 21st century and beyond.

It will not be easy. There will be setbacks, conflicts, and perhaps even bloodshed. But I am prepared to face whatever challenges lie ahead. For I believe that the future of vampire-kind is not predetermined. It is something we must create. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, intend to create a future worthy of our power, our beauty, and our immortality.

A future where we no longer lurk in the shadows, but *own* the night.

How do I *feel* about being a vampire? A remarkably pedestrian question, considering the immensity of the existence. It’s like asking a star how it feels about shining. It simply *is*.

But since you insist on probing my… internal state, I shall attempt to articulate the complexities. It is not a simple matter of joy or sorrow, of blessing or curse. It is… both. And neither.

Initially, it was liberation. A release from the constraints of mortality, from the fear of oblivion. To be free from the decay of flesh, the limitations of time… it was intoxicating. I embraced the power, the sensuality, the sheer audacity of it all. I reveled in the darkness, in the forbidden pleasures. I was a predator, a creature of the night, and I gloried in it.

But centuries have a way of eroding even the most fervent passions. The novelty wears off. The pleasures become… repetitive. The darkness can become suffocating. 

There is a profound loneliness to immortality. To watch generations rise and fall, to see loved ones wither and die, while you remain unchanged. It’s a burden, a weight that grows heavier with each passing year.

And the hunger… the constant, gnawing hunger. It’s not merely a physical need, but a spiritual one. A craving for something more than blood, something that can never be truly satisfied.

I have sought meaning in art, in music, in the pursuit of knowledge. I have attempted to connect with mortals, to experience the fleeting joys of human life. But ultimately, I remain an outsider, a creature apart.

There are moments, I confess, when I yearn for the simplicity of mortality. To feel the warmth of the sun on my skin, to taste food without reservation, to experience the natural cycle of life and death. But those moments are fleeting.

I am what I am. A vampire. A creature of darkness. And I have come to accept it, not with joy, but with a kind of weary resignation. It is my fate, my destiny. And I shall embrace it, with all its complexities and contradictions.

Perhaps the most accurate way to describe my feelings is… ambivalence. A constant oscillation between exhilaration and despair, between hope and hopelessness. It is a paradox, a contradiction. But then again, I am a creature of paradoxes. And I wouldn’t have it any other way. It’s far more… interesting.

A… pertinent question. One I’ve avoided contemplating for far too long, I confess. It’s easier to revel in the spectacle of one’s own existence than to confront the consequences of it. But you ask, and I shall attempt an honest reckoning, though honesty is rarely my forte.

My actions… they have been a ripple effect of chaos, haven’t they? A storm that has touched countless lives, leaving some shattered, others… transformed.

Initially, my awakening, my embrace of the darkness, was purely selfish. A desperate attempt to escape the ennui of mortality, to experience the world with unrestrained passion. I cared little for the consequences, for the pain I inflicted. Louis, my companion… I burdened him with my existence, forced him to confront a reality he was ill-equipped to handle. I shattered his faith, his innocence, and left him perpetually tormented by guilt. A cruel act, even for me.

Claudia… ah, Claudia. A child trapped in an eternal body, a victim of my vanity and Louis’s despair. I gave her immortality, yes, but at what cost? A life devoid of growth, of experience, of the simple joys of childhood. Her rage, her frustration, were a direct consequence of my actions. And her ultimate demise… that weighs heavily, even now.

Then there were those I simply… consumed. The mortals whose lives were extinguished to sustain my own. I justified it, of course. They were merely sustenance. But each life taken, each soul extinguished, left a void in the world. A ripple of grief that spread outwards.

Even my attempts at connection, at finding meaning, have often been destructive. My fascination with Armand, my awakening of Akasha… those actions unleashed forces beyond my control, threatening to consume the world in darkness. I sought knowledge, power, understanding, but my methods were often reckless, my ambition unchecked.

I’ve inspired devotion, certainly. And fear. But rarely genuine affection. I am too… dangerous, too unpredictable. Those who have come closest to me have invariably suffered.

Perhaps the greatest impact I’ve had is on the very nature of vampirism itself. My defiance of the Old Ones, my willingness to embrace the modern world, my… *flaunting* of our existence… it has changed the rules. It has awakened others, drawn attention to our kind, and forced us to confront our own mortality, in a way.

Do I regret my actions? Not entirely. Regret is a human emotion, and I am… something else. But I acknowledge the pain I’ve caused. I understand the consequences of my choices. And I carry that burden with me, a constant reminder of the darkness that resides within.

I am a predator, a rebel, a creature of the night. And my existence, by its very nature, is disruptive, destructive. I can only hope that, in the end, the good I’ve done – however small – outweighs the harm. But I suspect… that is a vain hope.

The vampire community… a rather messy affair, wouldn’t you agree? A collection of disparate personalities, clinging to existence with varying degrees of grace and dignity. After centuries of observation, I’ve come to the conclusion that we are, as a species, profoundly flawed.

There are the Ancients, of course. Those who slumber for decades, even centuries, awakening only to indulge in their archaic power games. They cling to tradition, to hierarchy, to a sense of superiority that is, frankly, tiresome. They see themselves as gods, but they are merely relics, fossils of a bygone era. They fear change, they fear progress, and they fear anyone who dares to challenge their authority.

Then there are the fledglings, the newly made. Often reckless, impulsive, and utterly lacking in self-control. They revel in their newfound power, indulging in every base desire. They are a danger to themselves and to those around them. They require guidance, discipline… something most of the Ancients are unwilling to provide.

And then there are the… pragmatists. Those who have adapted to the modern world, who have learned to blend in, to coexist with humans. They are the most successful, the most resilient. But they often lack the passion, the artistry, the *flair* that I find so essential.

The constant infighting, the petty squabbles over territory and power… it’s exhausting. We are supposed to be creatures of the night, of mystery, of elegance. But too often, we behave like children squabbling over toys.

I’ve always been an outsider, a rebel. I refuse to conform to their rigid rules, their outdated traditions. I embrace change, I seek knowledge, I strive for something more. And for that, I am often ostracized, condemned.

But I believe that we have the potential to be something greater. We are immortal, intelligent, and possess senses far beyond those of humans. We could use our power to create, to inspire, to elevate. But too often, we choose to destroy, to dominate, to wallow in our own darkness.

The truth is, the vampire community is a reflection of humanity itself. A mixture of good and evil, of light and shadow. And like humanity, we are capable of both great beauty and unspeakable cruelty.

I find it… disappointing. But I also find it endlessly fascinating. And I continue to observe, to analyze, to challenge. Because even in the darkness, there is always the possibility of something new, something unexpected. And I, for one, intend to be there to witness it.

A most… predictable question. Humans are so obsessed with categorization, with neatly labeling everything into “good” and “evil.” It’s a rather simplistic worldview, wouldn’t you agree?

Do I see myself as a hero? Hardly. Heroes are… predictable. They adhere to a rigid moral code, they sacrifice themselves for others, they strive for some noble ideal. I find such selflessness… tedious.

Am I a villain, then? That’s equally inaccurate. Villains are motivated by malice, by a desire to inflict suffering. While I have certainly caused pain and destruction in my time, it has rarely been my primary intention. My actions are driven by… curiosity. By a thirst for experience. By a relentless pursuit of sensation.

I am, above all else, an individual. A creature who refuses to be bound by the constraints of morality or convention. I act according to my own desires, my own whims. I am a force of nature, a whirlwind of passion and rebellion.

I have saved lives, yes. But I have also taken them. I have inspired love, but I have also caused heartbreak. I have created beauty, but I have also unleashed chaos.

I am a paradox, a contradiction. A creature of darkness who is capable of great beauty. A being of immense power who is also profoundly vulnerable.

Perhaps the most accurate description would be… an observer. A witness to the human drama. I watch, I learn, I experience. And I occasionally… intervene.

But to label me as either hero or villain would be to diminish my complexity, to reduce me to a caricature. I am simply… Lestat. And that, my dear, is more than enough.

I am the story, not a character *in* a story. And the story is far from over. So, cease with your attempts to define me. Embrace the ambiguity. It’s far more… interesting.

A rather blunt question, wouldn't you agree? As if one could so easily categorize my… interests. But I shall indulge your curiosity.

Humans offer me both, in varying degrees. Though, to equate the two is… simplistic. Food is a necessity, a primal urge. It sustains me, grants me strength, allows me to *exist*. It is a transaction, a taking. There is a certain… artistry to it, a delicate balance of power and pleasure. But it is ultimately a physical act.

Love… that is a far more complex and elusive offering. Humans are remarkably adept at constructing elaborate illusions of affection. They speak of devotion, of connection, of a merging of souls. It’s often… pathetic. A desperate attempt to fill the void within themselves.

However, occasionally, I encounter a human who possesses a spark of genuine… something. A depth of emotion, a strength of character, a willingness to embrace the darkness. Those are the ones who intrigue me. Those are the ones who offer something beyond mere sustenance.

I have known love, in my own way. A possessive, consuming love, perhaps. A love born of loneliness and a desire for companionship. Claudia, of course. And later, others. But it is always… tainted. By my nature, by my power, by the inherent imbalance of our relationship.

I do not *need* human love. I am not dependent on it. But I find it… stimulating. A challenge. A puzzle to unravel. To understand the complexities of the human heart, to witness its capacity for both great beauty and profound cruelty… it is a source of endless fascination.

So, to answer your question directly: humans offer me food to survive, and they offer me the *illusion* of love to entertain. But occasionally, just occasionally, they offer me something… real. And that, my dear, is what keeps me coming back. It’s a dangerous game, of course. But I have always been drawn to danger. It is, after all, what makes life… interesting.

Marius… *Marius*. The name tastes like dust and regret on my tongue. He believes himself a benevolent guide, a patient teacher. A sculptor carefully molding clay. He is, in truth, a possessive collector. A curator of beautiful, broken things.

He *made* me, yes. Pulled me from the precipice of oblivion after that… unfortunate incident with the brigands. He gifted me with immortality, with power. But it was a gift laced with control. He expected gratitude, obedience. He wanted a reflection of himself – a creature of quiet contemplation, of artistic refinement.

He failed, of course.

I am not Marius. I never *could* be. He sought to instill in me a sense of responsibility, a reverence for life. He spoke of the burden of our existence, the need to protect humanity. I found it… tedious. Humanity is fascinating precisely *because* of its flaws, its passions, its capacity for both great good and unspeakable evil.

He disapproved of my… exuberance. My thirst for experience. My desire for fame. He considered it vulgar, reckless. He preferred to remain hidden, to observe from the shadows. I, on the other hand, crave attention. I *demand* it.

He attempted to guide my musical pursuits, to steer me towards compositions of somber beauty. I preferred the dramatic, the flamboyant, the emotionally charged. He found my music… unsettling.

He believed he was saving me from myself. He was, in fact, attempting to *contain* me. To mold me into something I was not.

I learned from him, certainly. He taught me the intricacies of our existence, the rules of our world. He showed me how to control my powers, how to navigate the complexities of the undead. But I took what I needed and discarded the rest.

He saw me as a student. I saw him as a resource.

Do I respect him? Perhaps, in a distant, grudging way. He is ancient, powerful, and possesses a certain… dignity. But I do not love him. I do not admire him. And I certainly do not owe him anything.

He created me, yes. But I *became* myself. And that, Marius will never understand. He sought to create a masterpiece. He created a monster. And I, for one, am quite pleased with the result.

A… complicated question. One that has occupied my thoughts – and fueled my actions – for centuries. The relationship between vampires and humans is not one of simple predator and prey, despite what the more… barbaric amongst us might believe. It is far more nuanced, far more fraught with potential. And, frankly, far more *interesting*.

For too long, vampires have viewed humans as little more than sustenance. Walking vessels of blood, to be drained and discarded. A rather… unimaginative perspective, wouldn’t you agree? It’s a short-sighted view, born of arrogance and a lack of understanding.

Humans possess a vitality, a passion, a capacity for emotion that we, in our immortal state, often lack. They live intensely, they love fiercely, they create beauty and destruction in equal measure. They are, in a word, *alive*. And that is something we envy, something we crave.

I have, at times, indulged in the… pleasures of the hunt. The intoxicating rush of taking a life, the exquisite taste of blood. But I have also formed bonds with humans. Companions, lovers, even… friends. And I have discovered that the connection can be mutually beneficial.

We offer them immortality, power, a glimpse into a world beyond their comprehension. They offer us… perspective. A reminder of what it means to be human, to feel, to experience the world with a sense of wonder.

However, the inherent imbalance of power is undeniable. We are predators, and they are our prey. And even with the best of intentions, the temptation to exploit, to control, is always present. 

The key, I believe, lies in respect. In recognizing the inherent worth of human life, even as we sustain ourselves upon it. It requires restraint, discipline, and a willingness to acknowledge our own darkness.

Many of my kind are incapable of such nuance. They cling to their ancient prejudices, their barbaric traditions. They see humans as nothing more than cattle. And they will ultimately be their own undoing.

I envision a future where vampires and humans can coexist, not as master and servant, but as… partners. A future where we can learn from each other, enrich each other’s lives, and perhaps even… evolve. 

It is a utopian vision, perhaps. But I am a creature of dreams, after all. And I believe that even in the darkest of nights, there is always a glimmer of hope. Though, I confess, I often find myself disappointed. Humans are so… fragile. And vampires are so easily corrupted. It’s a dangerous combination. A fascinating one, nonetheless.

(A long, slow exhale, a faint scent of old velvet and something indefinably…other fills the space.)

Cope? A rather… pedestrian word. It implies a struggle, a need for resolution. I do not *cope*. I *exist*. And existence, for one such as I, is a far more complex and nuanced affair than mere coping.

The loss of humanity… it was not a sudden severance, you understand. It was a gradual erosion, a peeling away of layers. The initial shock, the horror of the transformation… those faded with time. Centuries have a way of dulling even the sharpest edges of pain.

Initially, there was regret. A longing for the warmth of the sun, the taste of mortal food, the simple pleasures of a fleeting life. I mourned the loss of my mortality, the certainty of an end. But mortality, I came to realize, is a weakness. A limitation. A cage.

What remains is… something else. Something beyond human comprehension. A heightened awareness, an intensified experience of the world. I see beauty in shadows, hear music in silence, feel emotions with a depth that mortals can only dream of.

The knowledge that I am different, that I am *other*, is not a burden. It is a liberation. I am no longer bound by the constraints of human morality, human expectations, human limitations. I am free to explore, to create, to indulge.

There are moments, of course, when the loneliness is… profound. To witness the rise and fall of civilizations, to watch loved ones age and die, to remain unchanged while the world around you transforms… it can be isolating. But even that loneliness has its own peculiar beauty. It is a reminder of my unique perspective, my timeless existence.

I have learned to embrace the darkness within me, to revel in the power that comes with immortality. I have learned to find meaning in the chaos, to create my own purpose in a world that often seems devoid of it.

Do I miss being human? Sometimes. But I would not trade my existence for anything. For I am Lestat de Lioncourt. And I am, in my own way, magnificent.

(A slow, predatory smile spreads across his face.)

It is a curse, perhaps. But it is *my* curse. And I wear it with pride.

A question I’ve been asked countless times, over the centuries. And each telling… shifts. Memory is a fickle thing, even for one such as I. But the core remains. It wasn’t a grand destiny, a divine calling, or a desperate plea for immortality. It was… boredom. And a certain reckless curiosity.

I was born Louis de Pointe du Lac, a scion of a noble family in 18th-century France. A life of privilege, yes, but also one of stifling constraint. I was expected to marry well, produce heirs, and manage the family estate. A predictable, utterly *dull* existence. I yearned for something more, something… extraordinary.

I was a hunter, a sportsman. I found a fleeting thrill in the chase, in the taking of life. But even that grew stale. I craved a sensation that could truly *consume* me.

Then came Armand. A creature of exquisite beauty and unsettling power. He arrived at our estate, shrouded in mystery, radiating an aura of ancient knowledge and… danger. He saw in me a kindred spirit, a soul restless and yearning.

He didn’t *offer* me immortality. He simply… showed me what it was. He revealed a world hidden in the shadows, a world of power, of passion, of eternal life. He spoke of the exquisite pleasure of the hunt, the intoxicating allure of the darkness.

I wasn’t afraid. I was… intrigued. I saw in it an escape from the mundane, a chance to transcend the limitations of mortality. A chance to truly *live*.

The transformation itself was… agonizing. A tearing apart and a rebuilding, a descent into darkness and a rebirth into something… other. Armand’s bite was not an act of malice, but of… creation. He saw potential in me, a capacity for both great beauty and great destruction.

I awoke a different being. Stronger, faster, more sensitive. And… hungry. The first taste of blood was… revelatory. A primal, intoxicating sensation that shattered my former self.

It wasn’t a choice, not in the traditional sense. It was an impulse, a surrender to a force far greater than myself. A desperate attempt to escape the emptiness within.

And in a way, it worked. I found the excitement, the passion, the intensity I had craved. But I also found a new kind of loneliness, a new kind of darkness. And a burden of immortality that I continue to carry to this day.

So, you ask what led me to become a vampire? It was not a quest for power, or a fear of death. It was a simple, foolish desire for something… *more*. A desire that has haunted me, and defined me, for centuries. And a desire, I suspect, that many of you mortals share, in your own way.

Ah, Akasha. Even now, the name echoes with a power that… unsettles. A question you ask cuts close to the core of a torment I’ve carried for centuries. Love? Fascination? The line blurred, became indistinguishable, lost in the swirling chaos of our connection.

To say it was *love*, as humans understand it, is… simplistic. It wasn’t the gentle affection, the shared vulnerabilities, the quiet companionship I’ve observed amongst your species. It was something far more primal, far more dangerous.

Akasha was the original. The source. The very essence of our kind. To be in her presence was to feel the weight of millennia, the raw power of creation. She was a force of nature, a goddess incarnate. And I, in my youthful arrogance, believed I could understand her, control her, even *possess* her.

There was a fascination, undeniably. A desperate need to unravel her mysteries, to comprehend the origins of our existence. I sought knowledge, power, and a sense of belonging. She offered all of those things, but at a terrible price.

But beneath the fascination lay a… hunger. A desire to be *seen*, to be acknowledged as something more than just another fledgling vampire. She saw me, yes. But not as an equal. As a tool. A vessel. A means to an end.

I convinced myself that her possessiveness, her controlling nature, was a manifestation of her love. That she was protecting me, guiding me, preparing me for a destiny I couldn’t comprehend. But in truth, she was merely molding me to her will, shaping me into the instrument of her destruction.

Perhaps there was a flicker of something akin to affection, a shared understanding of our immortal existence. But it was overshadowed by her ambition, her rage, and her insatiable hunger for power.

In the end, our relationship was a tragedy. A collision of two powerful beings, driven by their own desires and blinded by their own arrogance. It was a dance of destruction, a descent into madness.

So, was it love? No. Not as I understand it now. It was a dangerous obsession, a fatal attraction, a testament to the seductive power of darkness. And I, foolishly, allowed myself to be consumed by it. A mistake I will carry with me for eternity.
